div.ab:
This the Ancients have diuersly distinguished; but at this present it is divided by John Leo of
Africa, into foure chiefe parts; Barbaria, Numidia, Libya, and the Land of Negros. Barbarie,
which is accounted the best, they circumscribe with the Atlantick & Mediterranean seas; with
mount Atlas, & whither region of Barca bordering upon Ægypt. Numidia, called by the
inhabitants Biledulgerid, and abounding with Dates (for which cause the Arabians call it by no
other name, but the Date-bearing region) is bounded Westward by the Atlantick Ocean;
Northward by mount Atlas; it stretcheth East as farre as the citie Caphsa, which is an hundred &
fiftie miles distant from Ægypt; and the sande Deserts of Libya embrace it on the South. Libya
the third part, is named in the Arabian tongue Sura, which word signifies a Desert. It begins East
from Nilus, and thence runneth West as farre as the Atlantick sea; Numidia lies to the North of it,
and the Land of Negros to the South. Now followeth the fourth part, which they call Nigritarum or
Nigritania, either from the inhabitants, who are of a blacke colour, or from the river Niger, that
runneth thorow the countrey. It is bounded by Libya, South by the Æthiopick Ocean; West by
Guinee, and East by the Kingdome of Gago. And here we are to note, that according unto their
division, all Africa is included within the Mediterranean, Atlantick, and Æthiopick seas and the
river Nilus; whereof Ægypt and Abassia are accounted parts of it, which we not unworthily
therefore proper to belong to Africa. For the true Africa containes at this day Prester Johns
Empire, which by all late Writers is ascribed to Africa. Wherefore with Ptolomy indeed it ought to
be bound by the Mediterranean sea and Ocean seas, rather than by any river whatsoever; and
it hath the forme of a Peninsula, being joined toward Asia by an Isthmos of small neck-land,
which lies between the Mediterranean sea and the gulf of Arabia. The South part hereof was
unknowne to our ancestors, till the yeere 1497, whereas Vasco de Gama first doubling the Cape
of Bona Speranza, and passing about all Africa, came to Calecut in East India. This Southerne
part by the Persians and Arabians is called Zangibar.
At the fore-sayd Cape of good hope the inhabitants are exceeding blacke; which we thought in
no wise to omit, because all men suppose the cause of blacknesse to be heat, and the
nearnesse of the Sunne; whereas the Sunne of it selfe forceth no more, than about the Streight
of Magellan (we measure the heat of the place, according to the position of the heavens and
distance from the Equinoctiall line) were now notwithstanding the people are reported to be
marvellous white. But if we will needs ascribe this blacknesse to the scorching of the Sun, let us
consider, that the same makes the Spaniards and Italians looke white; whereas they are equally
distant from the Equinoctiall with the inhabitants of the fore-sayd Cape; namely the one towards
the South, and the other towards the North. Prester Johns people are of a browne colour; in
Zanel and Mollala the inhabitants are cole blacke, yet all in one & the same distance from the
equator, and under the very same parallell of the heavens. And on the contrary, why did
Herodotus and Pindarus describe such as inhabite the same climate with themselves, namely
Colches, to be a blacke people, and curled haired? Herodotus in his Thalia makes the Indians
blacke like the Æthiopians; which the experience of our times confirmeth. I know Herodotus will
have the cause hereof to be the seede of the parents, which he sayth is not whiter, than of other
people, but blacke. To whom Possidonius also subscribeth, and imputeth the matter of all this
blacknesse unto Canicular heate, against which opinion I have nothing to allege. Let the truth of
the matter rest upon the authors credit. But this as many men thinke more strange; that in all
America there were no black people found besides a few only in one place called by them
Quarequa. What then is the efficient cause of this colour? Is it the drinesse of the heavens, or of
the earth? is it perhaps some hidden propriety of the soile? Or a kind of fat licentious nature in
the nature of men? Or is it all these variances in one? But these things we leave to be
considered by them, who more curiously search into the secrets of nature.
This portion of the world is called by the Greeks Libya, and by the Latines Africa, because it is
not moistened with extremity of cold: or (if we may credit some) of Afer one of the adventurers
posterity. Another derivation of the name you have (set downe by John Leo in the description of
his booke of the Description of Africa), who deriveth it from one blacke African, springing of the
stocke of Cham, who first inhabited that part of the Mediterranean sea, from Atlas, bounded by
the river Nilus, or rather as the best authors have taught us, the African soile called of the
Greekes Aphrice, Marce rubrum, and red sea. Herodotus reporteth, that Africa was first
unknowne till Cesars time, when it was found to be a third part of the inhabited world. Plinie the
like, and so doth Solinus. Caesar Scaliger gathereth of the word Africa, that it is a name of the
same import with aprica, that is, a sunne-shining place; for that this land lying open on every
side to the Sunnes visitation, seemed thereby to have beene named so little other than of
apricity. The principall regions of Africa have amongst themselves (as it were) a threefold
division: first, from Atlas in the West to the red sea and Arabia, whence it took the name of the
first inhabiters, or else from the colour of the people, for the most part blacke and duskie; the
second, to wit, the inner part of Africa, from Nilus to the Kingdome of Congo, is more temperate,
and not so much subject to the Sunnes heate; the third, which is next unto the South Pole, by
reason of the obliquity of the Zodiack, is more temperate than the former. The islands that
belong to Africa (some of which are expressed in the table) are Madagascar, the Canaries, the
Isles of Cape Verde, and St. Thomas situated under the equinoctiall, which aboundeth with
fruits.
Among the ancient Writers none have particularly described this region. But concerning the
same saith Isidore in his Etymologies; Hanno his navigation about Africa, in diversities; and
Iambulus his voyages, in Diodorus Siculus; and likewise Herodotus his Melpomene.
Bartholomeus de Glanvilla in his Image of the World reporteth the like. Of late Writers reade
also the Commentaries of Vasco de Gama, Franciscus Alvares, who travelled Æthiopia. But of
all others John Leo hath most exactly described it; as also Andrew Thevet, and Francis Alvarez,
both travellers of Africa. Concerning the river Nilus, the greatest in all the world, you have the
letters of John Ramusio and Jerome Fracastorius. Of Africa itself, as by me read at large in the
second volume of Mr. Richard Hakluyts English Voyages.
